FRIDAY, APRIL 16, 1937

A Moratorium On Truth?
According to the sentiments expressed by one of the
students here and, from our observations shared by
many others—the University should stop thinking—
at least for a while.
Why? Because the Johns Hopkins is in the midst of
a financial campaign and presumably those who are
expected to contribute want to be sure that academic
freedom is non-existent. Presumably they shell out only
so that the Hopkin's scholars think as they do. They
give money, so some claim, to encourage only those
discoveries and ideas which support these donors.
But this writer of the letter and his confreres do not
go all the way in urging us to cease any analysis or
criticism of the living out of the University's ideals in
some quarters. They only say—it is all right to discuss
everything in order to ascertain the proper conclusions.
It's all right to attack injustices. It's all right to defend
tree speech—but not now.
Yes, be hypocritical, lay low; keep quiet now. Let all
attacks on campus freedom of thought and expression
go by. Take it on the chin when injustices are committed. But only temporarily. Wait 'till we get enough
money to breath easier. Then we can think as we please
and seek the truth in the traditional Hopkins spirit.
This attitude is not only founded on exaggerated
fears and false premises, but its ideas and implications
are what we can best call "un-Hopkins." First of all
we disavow any statements from us (and as far as we
know from any other organization) to the effect that
the administration is suppressing free speech—in general—or in these two specific cases.
The letter writer and those who think like him have
peculiar—and erroneous --notions of what the University stands for. We "beefers" believe in the real tenets
of the Hopkins. We do not regard "Veritas Vos Liberabit" as a pet phrase to be slung about carelessly; we
jealously guard this motto as the guiding spirit, the
living ideal of the Hopkins. In fact, we want to make
sure that nothing interferes with the traditional academic freedom and liberal attitude --associated with our
University since its founding.
Fortunately, actual conditions tend to make us much
less pessimistic than this student. We can point to
widespread protest that greeted the assertion by one
of our Board of Trustees last year that the reason
money was slow in being raised was the radical element at the Hopkins. It is obvious that their fears of
a large radical section of our faculty or student body
are baseless.
The fact of the matter is that the Hopkins possesses
a rather conservative student body and still more conservative faculty. As the Supreme Court poll, and our
observations, show, we possess students and faculty
members who are far from radical—but who are, for
the most part, open-minded and tolerant of the views
of others.
We have more confidence in the Hopkins; we possess
more faith in the number of people who hold a similar
regard for the continuing of the Hopkins as the traditional home of academic freedom and liberal thought.
Because, should this University ever abandon its
characteristic features and cease to live up to its
motto—it ceases to exist as that institution of world
'renown. It ceases to be The Johns Hopkins University.
And if we do anything to undermine or change those
long-standing traditions during this financial campaign,
we will be obtaining money under false pretenses.

Deserving Promotion
We are pleased to announce the election of Murray
Kempton and Ben Root to the positions of managing
editor. These two fellows have served for almost two
years in steady service to the most active activity on
the campus. In academic rain or shine, the pair contributed towards putting out the NEWS-LETTER regularly. They well deserve this promotion.
Congratulations, fellows, and lots of luck in your
new positions!

The athletic revolution of the last decade left colleges and universities roughly segmented into two
camps; the strong and proselyting, aiming for large
gate receipts; and, the weak and amateur, aiming for
wholesome competition and fun for all. The Hopkins
withstood the juggernaut of professionalism that found
its way into too many of our institutions of learning,
including some of the most sanctimonious. It repelled
the new; stuck fast to the old.
Consequently—and it is a sad reflection—it became
the lot of the Hopkins student to explain to the uninitiated outsider the why and wherefore of the Hopkins
reputation. "No," the Hopkins student had to say, "we
have given the world or, rather, the sports pages, no
Grange, Cagle, Thorpe; but, what of Welch, Kelly,
Osier, Holstead and Willoughby?" But, to the uninitiated
this was not, is not today an adequate reply.
So we say this to the uninitiated, and only beause
they are uninitiated: Watch our lacrosse team. It is
composed of Students come here to learn chemistry,
language, etc. Yet, it vies with the best on even terms.
Come out tomorrow and watch these amateurs play the
University of Pennsylvania. And watch a student body
getting a lot of fun looking on as its class mates play
in their spare time—because they like to play.

Let Justice Be Done
No one who attended the meeting last Friday for discussion of the Shils question and heard the speakers'
opinions can entertain any doubts on two main points.
First, in the absence of any evidence against, and the
full array of testimony for, the election of this student
to Phi Beta Kappa, one must contend that he deserves
and beyond all uncertainty should be awarded the key.
And secondly, that the method of choosing members is
one which can potentially continue to allow such injustices as this to arise.
We are happy to hear that a special meeting of Phi
Beta Kappa is to be held. We sincerely hope that justice will be done for this case and for the future,

It happened in Salem,Mass., on Februrary 12, 1877. The
young reporter attended a demonstration of inventor Bell's
new telephone — then "talked" his story to his paper in
Boston by telephone!
Though he didn't realize it, he was inaugurating a new
era in journalism. For today's newspapers could hardly exist
without the telephone.
Gathering and spreading news with lightning speed is just
one of the telephone's countless contributions to modern
life. And 300,000 Bell System people strive constantly to
make the service still better, still more useful.
Why not telephone home oftener?
Rates to most points are lowest after
7 P M. and all day Sunday.

Micro Analysis." Dr. Corwin has developed a super-sensitive balance for
this work, and presented a discusent in weighing to one gamma, the
one-millionth part of a gram, or about

The address opened with a presentation of the need for such refinement
in weights, when dealing with hormones, which at the present cost

Interfering factors, such as the vibrations
about $10,000,000 an ounce.

of a passing train or auto, animal
heat from the human body, and other
causes, such as dust, and humidity

unpleasant necessity of placing the
balance in an hermetically-sealed
chamber, and observing only through
a telescope, work has been done to
make a balance sensitive, and yet
useful.
It was in connection with this that
the discovery was made that a knifeedge of the hardest-known material,
sharpened so as to be invisible in the
field of a powerful microscope as a
surface, still showed wide variations,
which were found to be due to the
deforming of the edge as the weight
came upon it, much as an automobile
tire flexes under the weight of the
car.
Therefore, since the bearings are
lifted from the knife-edges when the
balance was idle, it .was found that
this "squashing" resulted in a bouncing motion when the weight of the
balance came on
bearing.

Elimination of this effect has greatly
improved the precision with which
measurements may be made.

this work was the ability, by proper
manipulation of the balance, to register the amount a diamond or sapphire
is compressed by the weight, say,
of a thin dime.

aside a goodly portion of sums delegated to them by the U. S. Government for the purpose of purchasing
long-needed uniforms for the Band.
Not being used to doing things in

were put in charge of the choice of
a suitable uniform to properly accent
and accentuate the dignity, the love
of luxurious drapery, and appreciation for the gaily-caparisoned, did

ideals.

had to lay hard cash right on the
line. Now the boys have just two
things to do, either raise the money

back. They have decided to keep

Civils Hold Second University Accepts
Annual Conference Grants and Library
The Second Annual Conference of
the Student Chapters of the American Society of Civil Engineers will
be held here at Hopkins on Monday,
April 19. The chapters participating
are those of the Catholic University
of America, the University of Maryland, the George Washington University, and the Johns Hopkins University.
The conference will open Monday
morning at 9.30 with registration in
Latrobe Hall. At 10 o'clock the visitors will be welcomed by President
Isaiah Bowman.
After President
Bowman's speech of weltome, Dr.
Ernst Cloos, eminent geologist, will
speak on a subject of interest to the
assembled students.
At 12 o'clock a buffet lunch will
be served at the Faculty Club. After
this, the students will make a series
of inspection trips. It has been arranged to inspect the Chevrolet assembly plant, the Bethlehem Steel
Co. plant at Sparrows Point, and the
new 29th Street Bridge, a concrete
monolithic arch, which is now in the
process of construction.
,Upon returning from the inspection trips the students will again
make their way to the Faculty Club,
where a banquet will be held. Mr.
Thomas F. Hubbard, a prominent
member of the Engineering Faculty,
will be toastmaster, and Dean of Engineering, E. R. Whitehead, will extend the welcome of the Hopkins
Faculty to the visitors.

At a recent meeting of the Board
of Trustees of the Johns Hopkins
University, gifts were accepted for
the University from the Rockefeller
Foundation, the Carnegie Institute,
and Dr. Howard Kelly.
The Medical School was the recipient of the largest of these. A
$45,000 grant from the Rockefeller
Foundation for two years, for the
support of Research in the Pavolovian and Psychobiological Laboratories of the Department of Psychiatry.
The Carnegie grant, $10,000, also
for two years, is for Endocrine Research, now under the direction of
Dr. John J. Abel of the Medical
School. The Kelly gift, by Dr. Howard A. Kelly, of the Medical School,
and one of the four original doctors
of the organization, consists of 584
bound and unbound volumes on
Africa exclusive of Egypt.

Med. School Will Speak
To Association
Students from
many
medical
schools throughout the country wilt
convene at the Johns Hopkins Medical
Schol this weekend in the fourth annual convention of the Association of
Medical Students.
The first meeting will be a luncheon
at 12.30 tomorrow at the Welch Library, and Dr. Alan Chesney, Dean
of the Hopkins Medical School, and
Dr. John P. Peters, Professor of Internal Medicine, Yale University Medical School, will speak.
Panel Discussion
The second afternoon meeting at
2.30 P. M. will be a panel discussion
on "Problems of Curriculum," and
"Requirments for Interneship." Dr.
John Wyckoff, Dean, New York University College of Medicine; Dr. W.
W. Oliver, Dean, Long Island College
of Medici,ne, and Dr. E. K. Marshall, Chairman of Curriculum Committee,
Johns
Hopkins
Medical
School, will speak, and several students will also report.
At 7.30 P. M., there will be a dinner
held at Levering Hall, and a Forum
on "Medicine and Social Security"
will be held. Dr. Mary Van Kleeek,
Russel Sage Foundation, will speak
on "Economic Aspects of Social Security"; Dr. James Warbasse, President of the Cooperative League of
America, will speak on "Social Security and Medical Care."
On Sunday morning business sessions will be held, and Dr. Henry E.
Sigerist, Director of the History of
Medicine Institute, will give the closing address.
There is a $2 registration fee for
the convention, and Pre Med Students in their last year are invited
to attend. Registration will be held
today at Levering Hall at the "Y"
office.

Once again we have a defender of
the use of the word "ain't." This
time it is the eminent Professor Harold H. Bender, who obtained his doctorate from this University and is at
present chairman of the department
of Oriental Languages and Literature
of Princeton. He asserts that it is
perfectly respectable to say "It ain't
so," whether disputing about the Supreme Court, the C. I. 0., or a lacrosse game.
Dr. Bender is considered one of
the world's best philologists and
etymologists. In the course of thirtytwo years of word-sleuthing, one of
his most interesting bits of detective
work ( which, incidentally, is of especial interest to some of us), had
to do with man's early drinking customs and habits. This was a result
of tracking down the homely "highball." He found, strangely enough,
that throughout the centuries in IndiaEuropean countries, when dynasties
rose and fell, and thousands of words
might be jettisoned, the name of the
favorite intoxicating drink of the
primitive tankard-wavers and elbowbenders remained unchanged.

FRIDAY, APRIL 16, 1937

A Moratorium On Truth?
According to the sentiments expressed by one of the
students here and, from our observations shared by
many others—the University should stop thinking—
at least for a while.
Why? Because the Johns Hopkins is in the midst of
a financial campaign and presumably those who are
expected to contribute want to be sure that academic
freedom is non-existent. Presumably they shell out only
so that the Hopkin's scholars think as they do. They
give money, so some claim, to encourage only those
discoveries and ideas which support these donors.
But this writer of the letter and his confreres do not
go all the way in urging us to cease any analysis or
criticism of the living out of the University's ideals in
some quarters. They only say—it is all right to discuss
everything in order to ascertain the proper conclusions.
It's all right to attack injustices. It's all right to defend
tree speech—but not now.
Yes, be hypocritical, lay low; keep quiet now. Let all
attacks on campus freedom of thought and expression
go by. Take it on the chin when injustices are committed. But only temporarily. Wait 'till we get enough
money to breath easier. Then we can think as we please
and seek the truth in the traditional Hopkins spirit.
This attitude is not only founded on exaggerated
fears and false premises, but its ideas and implications
are what we can best call "un-Hopkins." First of all
we disavow any statements from us (and as far as we
know from any other organization) to the effect that
the administration is suppressing free speech—in general—or in these two specific cases.
The letter writer and those who think like him have
peculiar—and erroneous --notions of what the University stands for. We "beefers" believe in the real tenets
of the Hopkins. We do not regard "Veritas Vos Liberabit" as a pet phrase to be slung about carelessly; we
jealously guard this motto as the guiding spirit, the
living ideal of the Hopkins. In fact, we want to make
sure that nothing interferes with the traditional academic freedom and liberal attitude --associated with our
University since its founding.
Fortunately, actual conditions tend to make us much
less pessimistic than this student. We can point to
widespread protest that greeted the assertion by one
of our Board of Trustees last year that the reason
money was slow in being raised was the radical element at the Hopkins. It is obvious that their fears of
a large radical section of our faculty or student body
are baseless.
The fact of the matter is that the Hopkins possesses
a rather conservative student body and still more conservative faculty. As the Supreme Court poll, and our
observations, show, we possess students and faculty
members who are far from radical—but who are, for
the most part, open-minded and tolerant of the views
of others.
We have more confidence in the Hopkins; we possess
more faith in the number of people who hold a similar
regard for the continuing of the Hopkins as the traditional home of academic freedom and liberal thought.
Because, should this University ever abandon its
characteristic features and cease to live up to its
motto—it ceases to exist as that institution of world
'renown. It ceases to be The Johns Hopkins University.
And if we do anything to undermine or change those
long-standing traditions during this financial campaign,
we will be obtaining money under false pretenses.

Deserving Promotion
We are pleased to announce the election of Murray
Kempton and Ben Root to the positions of managing
editor. These two fellows have served for almost two
years in steady service to the most active activity on
the campus. In academic rain or shine, the pair contributed towards putting out the NEWS-LETTER regularly. They well deserve this promotion.
Congratulations, fellows, and lots of luck in your
new positions!

The athletic revolution of the last decade left colleges and universities roughly segmented into two
camps; the strong and proselyting, aiming for large
gate receipts; and, the weak and amateur, aiming for
wholesome competition and fun for all. The Hopkins
withstood the juggernaut of professionalism that found
its way into too many of our institutions of learning,
including some of the most sanctimonious. It repelled
the new; stuck fast to the old.
Consequently—and it is a sad reflection—it became
the lot of the Hopkins student to explain to the uninitiated outsider the why and wherefore of the Hopkins
reputation. "No," the Hopkins student had to say, "we
have given the world or, rather, the sports pages, no
Grange, Cagle, Thorpe; but, what of Welch, Kelly,
Osier, Holstead and Willoughby?" But, to the uninitiated
this was not, is not today an adequate reply.
So we say this to the uninitiated, and only beause
they are uninitiated: Watch our lacrosse team. It is
composed of Students come here to learn chemistry,
language, etc. Yet, it vies with the best on even terms.
Come out tomorrow and watch these amateurs play the
University of Pennsylvania. And watch a student body
getting a lot of fun looking on as its class mates play
in their spare time—because they like to play.

Let Justice Be Done
No one who attended the meeting last Friday for discussion of the Shils question and heard the speakers'
opinions can entertain any doubts on two main points.
First, in the absence of any evidence against, and the
full array of testimony for, the election of this student
to Phi Beta Kappa, one must contend that he deserves
and beyond all uncertainty should be awarded the key.
And secondly, that the method of choosing members is
one which can potentially continue to allow such injustices as this to arise.
We are happy to hear that a special meeting of Phi
Beta Kappa is to be held. We sincerely hope that justice will be done for this case and for the future,

It happened in Salem,Mass., on Februrary 12, 1877. The
young reporter attended a demonstration of inventor Bell's
new telephone — then "talked" his story to his paper in
Boston by telephone!
Though he didn't realize it, he was inaugurating a new
era in journalism. For today's newspapers could hardly exist
without the telephone.
Gathering and spreading news with lightning speed is just
one of the telephone's countless contributions to modern
life. And 300,000 Bell System people strive constantly to
make the service still better, still more useful.
Why not telephone home oftener?
Rates to most points are lowest after
7 P M. and all day Sunday.

Continuing the annual affair instituted last year with
the Soph Frosh dance, the present first-year and secondyear students are sublimating their Hell Week into a
combined social affair.
Last year the dance was well-supported and the
pioneer effort was declared a success from all angles.
The two class worked together harmoniously and a
sizeable sum was earned for the respective class
treasuries.

to deserving and needy students, who

It was in connection with this that
the discovery was made that a knifeedge of the hardest-known material,
sharpened so as to be invisible in the

surface, still showed wide variations,

came upon it, much as an automobile

car.
Therefore, since the bearings are
lifted from the knife-edges when the
balance was idle, it .was found that
this "squashing" resulted in a bouncing motion when the weight of the

Civils Hold Second University Accepts
Annual Conference Grants and Library
The Second Annual Conference of
the Student Chapters of the American Society of Civil Engineers will
be held here at Hopkins on Monday,
April 19. The chapters participating
are those of the Catholic University
of America, the University of Maryland, the George Washington University, and the Johns Hopkins University.
The conference will open Monday
morning at 9.30 with registration in
Latrobe Hall. At 10 o'clock the visitors will be welcomed by President
Isaiah Bowman.
After President
Bowman's speech of weltome, Dr.
Ernst Cloos, eminent geologist, will
speak on a subject of interest to the
assembled students.
At 12 o'clock a buffet lunch will
be served at the Faculty Club. After
this, the students will make a series
of inspection trips. It has been arranged to inspect the Chevrolet assembly plant, the Bethlehem Steel
Co. plant at Sparrows Point, and the
new 29th Street Bridge, a concrete
monolithic arch, which is now in the
process of construction.
,Upon returning from the inspection trips the students will again
make their way to the Faculty Club,
where a banquet will be held. Mr.
Thomas F. Hubbard, a prominent
member of the Engineering Faculty,
will be toastmaster, and Dean of Engineering, E. R. Whitehead, will extend the welcome of the Hopkins
Faculty to the visitors.

of Trustees of the Johns Hopkins
University, gifts were accepted for
the University from the Rockefeller
Foundation, the Carnegie Institute,
and Dr. Howard Kelly.
The Medical School was the recipient of the largest of these. A
$45,000 grant from the Rockefeller
Foundation for two years, for the
support of Research in the Pavolovian and Psychobiological Laboratories of the Department of Psychiatry.
The Carnegie grant, $10,000, also
for two years, is for Endocrine Research, now under the direction of
Dr. John J. Abel of the Medical
School. The Kelly gift, by Dr. Howard A. Kelly, of the Medical School,
and one of the four original doctors
of the organization, consists of 584
bound and unbound volumes on
Africa exclusive of Egypt.

many
medical
schools throughout the country wilt

Schol this weekend in the fourth annual convention of the Association of
Medical Students.

Dr. John P. Peters, Professor of Internal Medicine, Yale University Medical School, will speak.
Panel Discussion
The second afternoon meeting at
2.30 P. M. will be a panel discussion
on "Problems of Curriculum," and
"Requirments for Interneship." Dr.
John Wyckoff, Dean, New York University College of Medicine; Dr. W.
W. Oliver, Dean, Long Island College
of Medici,ne, and Dr. E. K. Marshall, Chairman of Curriculum Committee,
Johns
Hopkins
Medical
School, will speak, and several students will also report.
At 7.30 P. M., there will be a dinner
held at Levering Hall, and a Forum
on "Medicine and Social Security"
will be held. Dr. Mary Van Kleeek,
Russel Sage Foundation, will speak
on "Economic Aspects of Social Security"; Dr. James Warbasse, President of the Cooperative League of
America, will speak on "Social Security and Medical Care."
On Sunday morning business sessions will be held, and Dr. Henry E.
Sigerist, Director of the History of
Medicine Institute, will give the closing address.
There is a $2 registration fee for
the convention, and Pre Med Students in their last year are invited
to attend. Registration will be held
today at Levering Hall at the "Y"
office.

Once again we have a defender of
the use of the word "ain't." This
time it is the eminent Professor Harold H. Bender, who obtained his doctorate from this University and is at
present chairman of the department
of Oriental Languages and Literature
of Princeton. He asserts that it is
perfectly respectable to say "It ain't
so," whether disputing about the Supreme Court, the C. I. 0., or a lacrosse game.
Dr. Bender is considered one of
the world's best philologists and
etymologists. In the course of thirtytwo years of word-sleuthing, one of
his most interesting bits of detective
work ( which, incidentally, is of especial interest to some of us), had
to do with man's early drinking customs and habits. This was a result
of tracking down the homely "highball." He found, strangely enough,
that throughout the centuries in IndiaEuropean countries, when dynasties
rose and fell, and thousands of words
might be jettisoned, the name of the
favorite intoxicating drink of the
primitive tankard-wavers and elbowbenders remained unchanged.

Cosmopolitan Club this Saturday,
April 17, at 8.30 P. M., in Levering
Hall by Cnarles Bullen, vice-president of the club.
Dan deLima, president of the Cosmopolitan Club, said of the discourse,
"It will discuss the events leading up
to and the sinking of a German fleet
of seventy battleships which the Germans themselves sank." Eullen will
then go on to explain how said ships
Were recovered by a British cornmany."
Everyone is invited to attend the
Meeting, after which refreshments
Will be served.
